issues.description: The problem statement (UML and task descriptions) refers to a class named 'ExcellencePark', but the template and the provided solution consistently use the name 'ExcellenceLand'. This class-name mismatch is structural: students reading the problem will be told to implement 'ExcellencePark' (and tests referenced in the tasks mention ExcellencePark), yet the starter files they receive (and the reference implementation) contain 'ExcellenceLand'. This will confuse students about which class to declare or implement and may cause test/class lookup failures.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the class name consistent across all artifacts. Either (A) update the problem statement (UML and task text) to use 'ExcellenceLand' instead of 'ExcellencePark', or (B) rename the template and solution files/classes to 'ExcellencePark' (including file names and constructor/getter names) and update tests accordingly. Ensure the UML, task descriptions, template filenames, and reference solution use the same class name so students are not confused.

issues.description: The park entity is named inconsistently: the problem narrative and the provided code use 'ExcellenceLand' (file/class names in template and solution), whereas the UML in the problem statement declares the class as 'ExcellencePark'. This mismatch can confuse students who try to map the UML class name to the starter code and the expected solution class.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the park class name across artifacts. Either rename the UML class from 'ExcellencePark' to 'ExcellenceLand' (recommended, matching the narrative and code), or rename the template/solution class files to 'ExcellencePark' so the UML, narrative and code use the same identifier. Updating the UML to 'ExcellenceLand' is the least disruptive fix and preserves the narrative wording.
